hair:

ground;

green,

case;

y, Which old men worship in their lctterd rest;

the French speak Engllsbt lhey are
mocking my flight, no doubt, but care no
thing about it if only get clear of their cur
sed clutches" o.away went, improving
my speed at every step, when all at once
! was brought to pull up, by coming IN

close upon them ere noticed my mistake
they were the enemy, and stood prepared to
receive the shock Of our soldiers who were
coming up to meet them. What took place
here know not. have merely dim recol-
lection of a dreadful shock between two bo-
dies OF men. | seemed to be the centre OF
struggle which ensued. and was levelled
to the earth by violent blow ON the temple,
This is all saw Of the battle of Waterloo.


u


There is here blanl, Of some weeks
in nv existence. / awnke as from a long
sleep, and found myself stretched upon bed
in dan kened chamber.-A moment before
seemed to be in the midst of slaughter; now
lay in the quietness of sick bed. | was
certainly i'll, for felt weak beyond measure,
aud could scarcely turn upon my couch. My
head swan, faint cloud f1oated before my
eyes, and ringings and whispcrings fell upon
my ears. lookingaround more attentivrly +,
4 | perceived a beautiful female form seated
bcside me. | gazcd on her as ON vision
| from heaven, and attempted to speak. She
observed my endeavors, and rising up placed
one slender finger upon my lips, in token OF
silence. | repeated my attempt at utterance,
when she shook her head and whispered,
with smile of the most afectionate tender-
ness. Nc farlez fus, mon cher Pou&
etcs encore troh f6ibte." For some time
could do nnthing but gaze on this lovely APP
partition Her countenance was lighted W
with the beauty not only Of form but of feel
ing, and appearing as She did under such
circumstances she seemed to my wandering
imagination more a creature OF the sky than
Of TIL, earthly planet.


! D4vs passed, and / was still waited on by
this ministering angel. She sat by the bed
side, bathing my heated temples and ad-
ministeing naurishment. Nor was she TIL e
only one who performed such kind offices
A lady older than herself and seemingly her
mother, would frequently enter the room
and lend her a helping hand. had also the
Consciousness of being waited upon ~ fhy,
sci4n; who came to visit me during the day


At times. also. perceived through the thin
curtains at the foot ef the bed, the shadow
of tall military officer, with a cooked hat,
and lofty feather, which lowered almost
TO the roof of the chamber. My senses rtl-
lied. began to think correctly, and was al
last by my gentle nurse permitted to speak.
I found that both her and her mother were
French, and understood no other language
Fortunately was we'll versed in that tongue,
which rendered our iuterc mrse easy and
agreeable. In the course OF ten days was
permitted by the physician to set up; and
it was then was told by my kind attendants
in answer to my anxious Inquiries, that
had been wounded in the battle Of Wat .roo
and lodged i'll their house by strange Ing
lish officer, who also resided Ghere, bot o
whom they knew nothing

We now took rather all obliqtc direction,
winding round very steep aseen, 1t the foot OF
the Rochcis Rouges. We found tliis part very
steep; and by ziglag movement we lett this
bare granite rock on our left hand, and arrived AT
a small plain which conducts to the Petits Alt-
lets, which are two rtl.ree uncovered peaks al
SO Of granite We did not reach Les Petts Mu
lets until half past ore o'clock. We sat down
ten minutes to recruit our strength, and drink a
glass Of wine to all our friends beiowi the guides
threw oil their knapsacks, and shaking each O.
ther cordially by the hand, seemed to forget all
their fatigues.


llnust acknowledge to you that looked at the
magnificent summit Of Mont Blanc, from this
point almost without consciousness. The strength
and force which we possess, when quietly walk.
ing through the beautiful valleys Of Switzerland
or Savoy, are we'll nigh exhausted when We ar
rive at the top of their stnpendous mountains. :

",
slipping; ard at the same time 50 steep, that the

The wind, as we continued to ascend, was bit

us scrons tout Fheurc." My other guide,

The dawn advances, yelled with roses,
Bring the morning draught Of blias;
The foseate sparkle morn dlscloSes,
Best reflects in cups like this.
On the tulips breasts are trembling


The dews-sweet tears of glowing day;
Those of beauty's cheek resembling


Love half regrets to kiss away
The gale, with perfiimed sigh, s stealing


From the gardens eden bowers,
oh quaff the wine--wherc Love, concealing,
Dews the heart with its pure showers.
Ruby its ripple bushes,


Rosc-lke is its bland perfume,
Near it, say, what cheek but ilushcs,


What lip but wears brighter bloom
An! why should rore-illumincd sages
To solitude such joys constran!
oh hastcnl here are pleasures pages,


Leave the binding scroll ofpaln.
Here learn Of IIafe-, and drink blissei,


Sweet as wine, from beauty's cheek;
Him, who enjoys the houri's kisses,


Alone may deem such transports weak.

and thermometer to them. My watch was flve
minutes past three O'Clock. At about five min
utes after three in the afternoon OF the 10th Au-
gust, 1925, the barometer marked fifteen inches
nine lines and one tenth French: and when We
left Coutet's house the day BEFORE it stood at rs
inches one line and one-tenth The thermome-
Ter was tllree-fourths of degree below zero,
Reaumur. Having made notes of these observa-
tions, Coutet pointed out the principal offsets
worthy of notice, and most clearly to be seen
from this highest point in our quarter of the
globe. 1t being three O'Clock, or little laters
the sun was in the southwest, and interrupted
our view very much in the direction of Geneva
and the Jura the Jura mountains formed our ho.
rison i'll that direction. Langress, the highest
town in France, we could not see, although it
has been said that the chain Of the Alps has been
seen from it. On the opposite side of Mont
Blanc the Apprentices were visible for vast e1-
tent, and the situation of Milan and Turin were
pointed out to u.s. We looked very carefully
and with an earnest wish to discover any thing
like the Mediterranean sea in the line over Ge-
noa, but cannot say that saw it. On the side
Of Switzerland the Jungfra', near Grindelwald,
was very conspicuous, as we'll as the Mont buets
the Diablerets, the Ghemmi, and St. Gothard;
more to the eastward, Mont Rosa was visible,
which is 2430 toscs above the level of the sea.
The Valley of Chamouni, and even its little vii.
lage, can be seen wish telescope. The convent
of the Grand st. Bernard was hid, owing to its
situation among the the mountains. We could
rot see much of the Alice Blanche, or Mont
Blanc, Immediately at its base on that side, ow-
ing TO the various projections, which, as it weres
grow from its sides.


The day was remarkably fne-there was not
cloud above our heads; but on many the less
er chains Of mountains, and on the Alpennines,
there we're light clouds and vapour.


Couiiet endeavoured to make me see star,
but either he was mistaken, or his eyes were bet.
ter than mine. walked to the extreme end OF
the summit, and looked over towards the MARI
time Alps: this Chain was very distinct. The
length Off the summit of Mont Blanc is two hun
dred PAGES, and nearly level. found difiicul-
ty in measuring the width, for the sides are an inn
mediate descent SO that did not know where
to begin or where to finish. The whole figure
may be understood as a hog's-back shape.-f
am told that the summit of this mountain has
been described as forming nearly a triangle; but
we did not find this to be the case now 1t ie
evident, from the drifts Of snow during the tur-
buent winds in winter, that its appearance may
change in twenty-four hours; and that which is
of triangular form to-day may be circular tos


morrow. The variety and changes i'll the drifts
Of snow on exposed plains, are sufficiently wei!
known to every traveller.


Every object seen from this summit (246O toss
es above the level fthe sra) becomes so dimi-
nutive, with the exception OF few principal
mountains, and so forc-shortened, that it seems
entirely to have changed its form and character.


The beautiful Ague du Midi, and those OF
Charlnoa, the delight and admiration OF every
stranger who visits Chamouni, are in some de.
gree lost i'll the general confusion; ought to
saw in truth, that no one particular object could
be seen distinctly: every thing appears SO
massed together, that all power of distinction IS
lost.


While stationary on the summit ofMont Blanc,
experienced a very peculiar sensation of light.
ness Of BODY, which was also felt by some of the


party to whom mentioned the circumstance. 1t
appeared as if could have passed the blade ofa
knife under my shoes, or between them and the
ice on which | stood. mentioned this fact to


Ebel, Mt Zurich, and also to other persons whom


| thought capable Of calculating the cause; but
: their explanations were not satisfactory. The
subject will, perhaps, serve to amlse your stu


ious bours: OILY vouch for the fact. The ra-
jyity ofthe air did not affect me quite so much or
the summit as when laboring through the deep


SHOWS and climbing the ascents on our passage,


during the ten hours were employed in as


cendng from Les Grands Mulets.


The sense of hearing was not interrupted, if
there had been any thing to heari the smell,
and power Of feeling, were not tllmnshedi but


the faculties of the mind were in less activity
The sky was of a very dark indigo blue; this


deep tint was, indeed, among the most remark


able features we observed. Being, as we were,
above all yapour and thick atmosphere, which
rises to certain height above the level of the


earth, the medium through which we saw it was


OF course more purei and we looked, asst were,
into dark ocean of infinite space. After having
well observed, as far as could be distinguished,
the principal objects within reach, and again exc


amined our glasses, the barometer was found to


remain steady: the thermometer, however, had


somewhat changed, and the mercury had fallen


very little below the point at which it was first
marked, three -fourths Of degree below zero Of
Reaumur. The wind began to feshen from the
southwest, and Coutet would not sufierus to re-
main.


The snow drifted from the neighbourlng noun
tans, and was hurrying along the surface OF the


summit, about half way up to our knees, put


none of it remained on the ice where we stood.


This drifting snow, meeting with resistance


such as the body or legs of q man, would soon ac-
cumulatc, not greatly to his comfort.


lhave mentioned to you before that We had
been ten hours coming from the Grands Mnlets
; "a the spot where we now stood. Although our
!. return would not occupy more than half that


fine. still it was already late and we might, there


fore. by some accidental delay, have to cross the
:. DANGEROUS Glacier de Tacconai III the dark, OF
: else sleep unshetercd on the ice. The injunc-
Z t;ons of the guides were positive, and we were

from being Of pleasant kind, and believe
those Of my comrades were not much more
agreeable. We knew that doubtful battle |
had been fought at Quartre Bras, and were
assured that the Prussians had sustained
signal defeat at Ligny. This knowledge did
not contribute much to raise our spirits; and
when we observed the remnants OF the gal /
liant Scotch regiments which were almost
annihlated at the former place, and the
numbero of wounded brought in, we became

us, and that the French were not to be so
easily beaten as we had expected. How
ever, no one said word. Each moved on IN
dubious silence, resolved to do his best; but
nwardy cursing the i'll luck that brought
him there, and wishing himself at Dan or
Beersheba.


We were placed, as i'll luck would have
X, in the very front of the battle. Our rcgl-
lment was known to be good ono, and the
Colonel steel to tile back bone; and, in truth
we needed all onr qualities, Tor we were

3acke,, by a strong body Of foot and cuiras-
sers. My uncle rode up to me: Tom. you
dog, mind your colors.'-'l wish you and the

could not help it, tor began to ieel con-
4 foundcdiy uncomfortable, The battle, con

last his artillery, succeeded by showers OF
/ musketry. opened upon US. we returned
/ these compliments in the same style, and


doubtless with good effect. | shall never

nv brave buys-hrc away was heard ON
ali sides from the officers encouraging their

During the whole of this time | stood IN

ors waving over my head. The men were

lonper was 50 stupitied hardly knew what

me and look ed up, and saw him IN the act


of leading on his men to the charge At TINS

s;dc The standard was raised by sergeant,


,rho was almost instantly killed. "tine en-

can 10 reflect how much better should have

nv rascally Trcnchman, who fancied me tor
n shot. Honour is very pretty thihs to

ring war it is one Of thr uslIcst things N the

would rather, any day, die ike CHRISTIAN
, on my bed, than be killed IN oattlc m any
, manner, however honorable, but TINS is

the charge. but the smoke was SO thick

advanced with the rest, because | knew that

Dot't suppose it was valour that led me on;

Of inscnsibity which rushes TO danger with

was SO confused that verify believed our

, It was only Rozinante that had been shot

l;np of an eve. He did not wait to be re-

happy, friend who will ever be klna' anu


nature raised above fatigue, and pam, an'


deatb-then, while the pains OF ivihs ar

ted out by the glories OF heaven, s'iu i,, Va Va

A FAMILY GROUP.
full articles.article:
1t was in fnll.blown June, twhen phubus glides
Down on his golden path to rhetis bowers,)
That, in an antique room whose massy sides
Were oak, all overgrown with knots of flowers,
Broad leaves, and punches Of the swollen grape,
And many dream carved out in horid shapc,
A stately couple sate:--the dame wa, fair.
Though Time with silver hands had touch'd her


hair:


Her husband, bald enough for Casar's crown,
Wore, like some triumph past, his soldiers trown,
Wherewith he daunted once the mailed foe
Near them, (and as asnow-tlrop aye will blow
More beautiful in ice than summers shaded
All passion-pale, there safe down-eyed maid,
Their daughter, whose small fingers piled some


toll


Till flowers came blushing from the barren soil;
Some white, some star-cyed, some all youth, like


May,


And some lit up with love, like crimsonng day.
They had no light, and yet all sprang and -four


ish'd


ny her intense and passionate glanccs nonrislll
Tolfc as love is which uncherisll'd dies
The pensce turning but its golden eyes;
Blue yioets, the springs treasure, ever found
In that sweet tempest, which first wakes the


ground;


And .iacinths here, and there the rose was born
Surrounded BY its uuforgotten thorn!
ohehl tney safe In tnN old 5othlc room,
Where Darkness watch'd the Day, Showers of


perfume


Came blown in through the clouds Of jasmine


green,


Which laced the windows while, within, scarce


seen,


Rose pictured pannels. all hung round with


thought,


Which EIolbien or the nightly yantlyke wrought;
AND cushon'd seats, high, deep, and shaped for


case;


And carpets from beyond the Persian seas;
And sculptured tables and mighty range
Uibooks, those true friends who do never change,
Aut haunt with the odorous wisdom ever,
And endless music, like running river
There There stood Philosophy. patient guest,
y, Which old men worship in their lctterd rest;
There Truth, the Science, perfect made and
plain


lfom1nce, which IS the truth Of Joy and pains
There blood.red History, mad with angry wars;
There gallant Memoirs, iush'd with gentler scarsi
ana many volume old which will not die,
and the soul guiding dreams of Poesyi

the French speak Engllsbt lhey are
mocking my flight, no doubt, but care no
thing about it if only get clear of their cur
sed clutches" o.away went, improving
my speed at every step, when all at once
! was brought to pull up, by coming IN
front of forest of bavonets, bristling from
a dense body of infantry before me. was
close upon them ere noticed my mistake
they were the enemy, and stood prepared to
receive the shock Of our soldiers who were
coming up to meet them. What took place
here know not. have merely dim recol-
lection of a dreadful shock between two bo-
dies OF men. | seemed to be the centre OF
struggle which ensued. and was levelled
to the earth by violent blow ON the temple,
This is all saw Of the battle of Waterloo.


u


There is here blanl, Of some weeks
in nv existence. / awnke as from a long
sleep, and found myself stretched upon bed
in dan kened chamber.-A moment before
seemed to be in the midst of slaughter; now
lay in the quietness of sick bed. | was
certainly i'll, for felt weak beyond measure,
aud could scarcely turn upon my couch. My
head swan, faint cloud f1oated before my
eyes, and ringings and whispcrings fell upon
my ears. lookingaround more attentivrly +,
4 | perceived a beautiful female form seated
bcside me. | gazcd on her as ON vision
| from heaven, and attempted to speak. She
observed my endeavors, and rising up placed
one slender finger upon my lips, in token OF
silence. | repeated my attempt at utterance,
when she shook her head and whispered,
with smile of the most afectionate tender-
ness. Nc farlez fus, mon cher Pou&
etcs encore troh f6ibte." For some time
could do nnthing but gaze on this lovely APP
partition Her countenance was lighted W
with the beauty not only Of form but of feel
ing, and appearing as She did under such
circumstances she seemed to my wandering
imagination more a creature OF the sky than
Of TIL, earthly planet.


! D4vs passed, and / was still waited on by
this ministering angel. She sat by the bed
side, bathing my heated temples and ad-
ministeing naurishment. Nor was she TIL e
only one who performed such kind offices
A lady older than herself and seemingly her
mother, would frequently enter the room
and lend her a helping hand. had also the
Consciousness of being waited upon ~ fhy,
sci4n; who came to visit me during the day


At times. also. perceived through the thin
curtains at the foot ef the bed, the shadow
of tall military officer, with a cooked hat,
and lofty feather, which lowered almost
TO the roof of the chamber. My senses rtl-
lied. began to think correctly, and was al
last by my gentle nurse permitted to speak.
I found that both her and her mother were
French, and understood no other language
Fortunately was we'll versed in that tongue,
which rendered our iuterc mrse easy and
agreeable. In the course OF ten days was
permitted by the physician to set up; and
it was then was told by my kind attendants
in answer to my anxious Inquiries, that
had been wounded in the battle Of Wat .roo
and lodged i'll their house by strange Ing
lish officer, who also resided Ghere, bot o
whom they knew nothing

Itiday, ,3igtsS' IS, 1925.


We now took rather all obliqtc direction,
winding round very steep aseen, 1t the foot OF
the Rochcis Rouges. We found tliis part very
steep; and by ziglag movement we lett this
bare granite rock on our left hand, and arrived AT
a small plain which conducts to the Petits Alt-
lets, which are two rtl.ree uncovered peaks al
SO Of granite We did not reach Les Petts Mu
lets until half past ore o'clock. We sat down
ten minutes to recruit our strength, and drink a
glass Of wine to all our friends beiowi the guides
threw oil their knapsacks, and shaking each O.
ther cordially by the hand, seemed to forget all
their fatigues.


llnust acknowledge to you that looked at the
magnificent summit Of Mont Blanc, from this
point almost without consciousness. The strength
and force which we possess, when quietly walk.
ing through the beautiful valleys Of Switzerland
or Savoy, are we'll nigh exhausted when We ar
rive at the top of their stnpendous mountains. :
The mind becomes worn down by tatiguc,as we'll
as by the changes the mind must necessarily un-
derro in passing through these different atmos-
phcres; and its powers are eneTvated almost 10
annihilation. However, though weary and tee
feeble enough. we had no thought OF abandoning
our object. Dr. Clark and two guides led the
way; Coutet and Pierre Simon assisted met
their aid here is very essential for this last ascent
",
slipping; ard at the same time 50 steep, that the
surface appears sometimes nearly cl Sc to your
face.


The wind, as we continued to ascend, was bit
terly cold. We had tied some extra hand'Ser-
chiefs over our ears and chin, and Coutet button
ed up closely his Alpine jacket, saying to me
two or three times, by way of consolation, mo
us scrons tout Fheurc." My other guide,
Simon. had never been up; and though his
strength and spirits had not failed him, he com
planned, and suffered good deal from pain il
his eyes. Within short distance from Les Pc
tits Mulct4, forgot to mention to you, that We
saw very near to us, two birds, which the guides
called ssCorneilles.' They were, think, what
Button calls lie choquard des Alpes; and Lin
nnus Corvus Pyrhocorax. They inhahit tht
highest Alps, ever amidst the eternal SHOWS, ahe
scarcely are seen on the mountains of the Jura
They feed on berries and wild trult, ane
such insects as are found near the edge OF the
snow:
| At two or three minutes after three O'Clock
we arrived at the utmost summit, the object OF al
our tolls, and Coutet called out "Nous Volci al
SONNET du Mont Blanc!" stood motonles
for some time to take generalview ofthls strang'
wild world Of mountains, and could scarcel,
believe where was! eproceedcd on toward
the centre, and Immediately fixed three poles u

full articles.article:
What, alasl shall dol'


My lover comes not to greet me;
sure he cannot be untrue,


He would not else have vow'd to meet me.


Without my love, all woe is me!
II the humming wheel ply,
:, How the threads are always breaking!
lospin tomorrow will try,


To-day l can't with heart that's aching.


Where, ah where, can my lover be.
As the calf, or kid, or lamb,
o.er the herbage lightly bounding,
Decks with anxious eye its dam,


Wsile with its bleat the woods are sounding


Just SO, my love, do seek thee.
@nen,, each morning, from the rll
x,,'', Mith my pitcher homeward vending,
without thought, my steps are still


iow'rd my lovers cottage tending


10 his door they carry me.

The following lines are verslllcation OF
nrose translation, by Sir VIM. Jones, OF
Persian Ode of Hafez.
The dawn advances, yelled with roses,
Bring the morning draught Of blias;
The foseate sparkle morn dlscloSes,
Best reflects in cups like this.
On the tulips breasts are trembling


The dews-sweet tears of glowing day;
Those of beauty's cheek resembling


Love half regrets to kiss away
The gale, with perfiimed sigh, s stealing


From the gardens eden bowers,
oh quaff the wine--wherc Love, concealing,
Dews the heart with its pure showers.
Ruby its ripple bushes,


Rosc-lke is its bland perfume,
Near it, say, what cheek but ilushcs,


What lip but wears brighter bloom
An! why should rore-illumincd sages
To solitude such joys constran!
oh hastcnl here are pleasures pages,


Leave the binding scroll ofpaln.
Here learn Of IIafe-, and drink blissei,


Sweet as wine, from beauty's cheek;
Him, who enjoys the houri's kisses,


Alone may deem such transports weak.

While linger here alone,


The migrate cares not for my anguisi!
Nay, perhaps, inconstant grown.


lie for SOM. othep maid may languish.


Can my love play false wilh mel
Still he comes nat,--lf the youth.
The truant youth, indeed forsahe me,
Heedless d his plighte1 truth,


TO the cold grave will bctakc me;


For what is life, love, without thee

and thermometer to them. My watch was flve
minutes past three O'Clock. At about five min
utes after three in the afternoon OF the 10th Au-
gust, 1925, the barometer marked fifteen inches
nine lines and one tenth French: and when We
left Coutet's house the day BEFORE it stood at rs
inches one line and one-tenth The thermome-
Ter was tllree-fourths of degree below zero,
Reaumur. Having made notes of these observa-
tions, Coutet pointed out the principal offsets
worthy of notice, and most clearly to be seen
from this highest point in our quarter of the
globe. 1t being three O'Clock, or little laters
the sun was in the southwest, and interrupted
our view very much in the direction of Geneva
and the Jura the Jura mountains formed our ho.
rison i'll that direction. Langress, the highest
town in France, we could not see, although it
has been said that the chain Of the Alps has been
seen from it. On the opposite side of Mont
Blanc the Apprentices were visible for vast e1-
tent, and the situation of Milan and Turin were
pointed out to u.s. We looked very carefully
and with an earnest wish to discover any thing
like the Mediterranean sea in the line over Ge-
noa, but cannot say that saw it. On the side
Of Switzerland the Jungfra', near Grindelwald,
was very conspicuous, as we'll as the Mont buets
the Diablerets, the Ghemmi, and St. Gothard;
more to the eastward, Mont Rosa was visible,
which is 2430 toscs above the level of the sea.
The Valley of Chamouni, and even its little vii.
lage, can be seen wish telescope. The convent
of the Grand st. Bernard was hid, owing to its
situation among the the mountains. We could
rot see much of the Alice Blanche, or Mont
Blanc, Immediately at its base on that side, ow-
ing TO the various projections, which, as it weres
grow from its sides.


The day was remarkably fne-there was not
cloud above our heads; but on many the less
er chains Of mountains, and on the Alpennines,
there we're light clouds and vapour.


Couiiet endeavoured to make me see star,
but either he was mistaken, or his eyes were bet.
ter than mine. walked to the extreme end OF
the summit, and looked over towards the MARI
time Alps: this Chain was very distinct. The
length Off the summit of Mont Blanc is two hun
dred PAGES, and nearly level. found difiicul-
ty in measuring the width, for the sides are an inn
mediate descent SO that did not know where
to begin or where to finish. The whole figure
may be understood as a hog's-back shape.-f
am told that the summit of this mountain has
been described as forming nearly a triangle; but
we did not find this to be the case now 1t ie
evident, from the drifts Of snow during the tur-
buent winds in winter, that its appearance may
change in twenty-four hours; and that which is
of triangular form to-day may be circular tos


morrow. The variety and changes i'll the drifts
Of snow on exposed plains, are sufficiently wei!
known to every traveller.


Every object seen from this summit (246O toss
es above the level fthe sra) becomes so dimi-
nutive, with the exception OF few principal
mountains, and so forc-shortened, that it seems
entirely to have changed its form and character.


The beautiful Ague du Midi, and those OF
Charlnoa, the delight and admiration OF every
stranger who visits Chamouni, are in some de.
gree lost i'll the general confusion; ought to
saw in truth, that no one particular object could
be seen distinctly: every thing appears SO
massed together, that all power of distinction IS
lost.


While stationary on the summit ofMont Blanc,
experienced a very peculiar sensation of light.
ness Of BODY, which was also felt by some of the


party to whom mentioned the circumstance. 1t
appeared as if could have passed the blade ofa
knife under my shoes, or between them and the
ice on which | stood. mentioned this fact to


Ebel, Mt Zurich, and also to other persons whom


| thought capable Of calculating the cause; but
: their explanations were not satisfactory. The
subject will, perhaps, serve to amlse your stu


ious bours: OILY vouch for the fact. The ra-
jyity ofthe air did not affect me quite so much or
the summit as when laboring through the deep


SHOWS and climbing the ascents on our passage,


during the ten hours were employed in as


cendng from Les Grands Mulets.


The sense of hearing was not interrupted, if
there had been any thing to heari the smell,
and power Of feeling, were not tllmnshedi but


the faculties of the mind were in less activity
The sky was of a very dark indigo blue; this


deep tint was, indeed, among the most remark


able features we observed. Being, as we were,
above all yapour and thick atmosphere, which
rises to certain height above the level of the


earth, the medium through which we saw it was


OF course more purei and we looked, asst were,
into dark ocean of infinite space. After having
well observed, as far as could be distinguished,
the principal objects within reach, and again exc


amined our glasses, the barometer was found to


remain steady: the thermometer, however, had


somewhat changed, and the mercury had fallen


very little below the point at which it was first
marked, three -fourths Of degree below zero Of
Reaumur. The wind began to feshen from the
southwest, and Coutet would not sufierus to re-
main.


The snow drifted from the neighbourlng noun
tans, and was hurrying along the surface OF the


summit, about half way up to our knees, put


none of it remained on the ice where we stood.


This drifting snow, meeting with resistance


such as the body or legs of q man, would soon ac-
cumulatc, not greatly to his comfort.


lhave mentioned to you before that We had
been ten hours coming from the Grands Mnlets
; "a the spot where we now stood. Although our
!. return would not occupy more than half that


fine. still it was already late and we might, there


fore. by some accidental delay, have to cross the
:. DANGEROUS Glacier de Tacconai III the dark, OF
: else sleep unshetercd on the ice. The injunc-
Z t;ons of the guides were positive, and we were

full articles.headline: From Elackwoods Magazine.
full articles.article:
from being Of pleasant kind, and believe
those Of my comrades were not much more
agreeable. We knew that doubtful battle |
had been fought at Quartre Bras, and were
assured that the Prussians had sustained
signal defeat at Ligny. This knowledge did
not contribute much to raise our spirits; and
when we observed the remnants OF the gal /
liant Scotch regiments which were almost
annihlated at the former place, and the
numbero of wounded brought in, we became
convinced that we had our work cut out tor
us, and that the French were not to be so
easily beaten as we had expected. How
ever, no one said word. Each moved on IN
dubious silence, resolved to do his best; but
nwardy cursing the i'll luck that brought
him there, and wishing himself at Dan or
Beersheba.


We were placed, as i'll luck would have
X, in the very front of the battle. Our rcgl-
lment was known to be good ono, and the
Colonel steel to tile back bone; and, in truth
we needed all onr qualities, Tor we were
drawn out opposite to formidable artillery,


3acke,, by a strong body Of foot and cuiras-
sers. My uncle rode up to me: Tom. you
dog, mind your colors.'-'l wish you and the
colors were at the devil, said 10 myself
could not help it, tor began to ieel con-
4 foundcdiy uncomfortable, The battle, con
siderable time before this, had commenced
! in various parts ot the line: the rest was loln-
ing in it rapidly; and IL now became our
turn to take part, as the enemy opposite was
advancing his iron front to the attack ~
last his artillery, succeeded by showers OF
/ musketry. opened upon US. we returned
/ these compliments in the same style, and


doubtless with good effect. | shall never


r. EtsSt fI.ri al N
tthc French guns In every quarter OF our


line an opening was made, and a number OF


men seen to drop, some killed outright and


some desperately wounded. The gaps


we're instantly filled by others, who stepped


forward from the rear ranks. 1t was the


first Of my battles, and felt. in spite OF all


my cfTo, IS, the trcpidaton and anxiety OF


noyiciatc. The noise, smoke, confusion and
destruction were horrible. Keep steady,


nv brave buys-hrc away was heard ON
ali sides from the officers encouraging their
men. The gallant fellows needed no en-
couraremcnt: they fought like lions Not


man thought of finchiug: the same indoml-


table British spirit animated them All.


During the whole of this time | stood IN


the very heart of the fight, the King col
ors waving over my head. The men were


draining fast around me. beard tho balls
whizzinrr like hail past my ears. In little
lonper was 50 stupitied hardly knew what
I did or where | was. At last ] heard the


yoice of nv uncle calling out, "Nell done.


Tom--that's brave boy. Take care Of youi
cnIors and stand last" His words aroused


me and look ed up, and saw him IN the act


of leading on his men to the charge At TINS


ooomcnt the ensign who bore the regimental
colors fell dead about ten Yards from my


s;dc The standard was raised by sergeant,


,rho was almost instantly killed. "tine en-


couraccment," !" thought l, "for flag bearers;


7 supposc nv turn will be next now BE-


can 10 reflect how much better should have


becn al home, following some pachc pro-
iession than standing here TO be picked by a.


nv rascally Trcnchman, who fancied me tor
n shot. Honour is very pretty thihs to
talk of on the peace establishments nut un-
ring war it is one Of thr uslIcst things N the
world and 50 little of soldier am !, mat
would rather, any day, die ike CHRISTIAN
, on my bed, than be killed IN oattlc m any
, manner, however honorable, but TINS is


diercssion.


the charge. but the smoke was SO thick
, that I could perceive nothing but his long,
, gonnt nhysiopnomv--su with his
. @ock cd hat. and white feather rising above
4 The lower part of his body, and the
whole of Rozinante were enveloped IN dark
ness. We we're guided entirely by bis up
per region, and followed him cn maSse. !
advanced with the rest, because | knew that
; stovinr behind would serve no purpose
Dot't suppose it was valour that led me on;
devil BIT. Itwas rather the blind impulse
Of inscnsibity which rushes TO danger with
out Knowing what it is about. rushed tor
ward as ifthe French were at my heels. l


was SO confused that verify believed our
men to be the enemy, and that was endea-


vorng to get out of the way. We had not
: nroceeded far when perceived my uncle's
head. cooked hat, and feather, which tow
cred above the smoke disappear like the


snuff of a candle. "The Colonel is gone,
cried several voices: they were mistaken.-
, It was only Rozinante that had been shot
under him. He was extricated by two gren.
: atiers, and got upon his legs in the twink-
l;np of an eve. He did not wait to be re-
mounted. but led the attack on foot rush
T, ;nr with such immense strides towards the
: : foe. that his men could scarcely keep pace
. with him.
"All is over now" thought, ."the Colo
!, = mel is taking to his heels, and why should
! not do the same p' Still did ], in my stu
pefaction, suppose that the French were be
. hind us, that it was duty to get out OF the
:, y way as soon as possible. l therefore re-
doubled my speed, but ! never let so the
